00001 #ifndef __EVTHREAD_H_
00002 #define __EVTHREAD_H_
00003 
00004 #include <corothread/cthread.h>
00005 #include <event.h> 
00006 #include <sys/socket.h>
00007 #include <sys/types.h>
00008 #include <cutils/dlist.h>
00009 
00010 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00011 
00012 /**
00013  * @defgroup EVLOOP
00014  * @brief event loop object.
00015  * The event loop  wraps a small user mode threading library where a user mode thread is created per connection.
00016  *
00017  * When a new connection is received via accept(2), then an EVSOCKET object is created that encapsulates this socket, 
00018  * and the socket is set to non blocking mode, and a user mode thread EVTHREAD is created that owns the new EVSOCKET object.
00019  * TCPACCEPTOR is the class that does all that.
00020  *
00021  * A user mode thread can own one or more EVSOCKET objects, it can read or write to an EVSOCKET object which has the API of a blocking socket.
00022  * when the socket blocks, (i.e. recv or send returns -1 and errno == EWOULDBLOCK) then the attached user mode thread is suspended, and control
00023  * returns to the event loop, the event loop schedules a different user mode thread, when an IO event occurs on a socket owned by that thread.
00024  *
00025  * A user mode thread (EVTHREAD) can create other sockets (EVSOCKET) that are then attached to the current thread.
00026  *
00027  * A use mode thread also owns a set of timer objects (EVTIMER), when the thread exits, all the timer objects are cleaned up.
00028  *
00029  * The event loop is implemented by libevent.
00030  *
00031  * Unlike other packages, where one can create several user mode thread and then has to cope with the problem of their synchronization, we keep things simple here.
00032  * There is one thread per connection, that is supposed to do protocol handling and processing, all on condition that processing does not involve heavy CPU intensive tasks.
00033  * If your problem does have such task, then there is also support for the Half-sync/Half-async pattern.
00034  * 
00035  * @{
00036  */
00037 typedef struct tagEVLOOP {
00038   struct event_base *ev_base;
00039   STACKS *stacks;
00040 } EVLOOP;
00041 
00042 EVLOOP * EVLOOP_init(STACKS *stacks );
00043 
00044 int EVLOOP_run( EVLOOP *loop );
00045 
00046 int EVLOOP_break( EVLOOP *loop );
00047 
00048 /**
00049  * @}
00050  */
00051  
00052 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00053 struct tagEVSOCKET;
00054 struct tagEVTHREAD;
00055 
00056 /**
00057  * @defgroup EVTHREAD
00058  * @brief user mode thread attached to an event loop
00059  * The thread owns one or more EVSOCKETS, it initially activated when the thread is created, and is futher activated when an IO event occurs on a EVSOCKET object 
00060  * owned by this thread.
00061  *
00062  * @{
00063  */
00064 
00065 typedef void (*EVTHREAD_PROC) ( struct tagEVTHREAD *thread, struct tagEVSOCKET *socket, void *user_ctx);
00066 
00067 typedef struct tagEVTHREAD {
00068   EVLOOP *loop;
00069   EVTHREAD_PROC thread_proc;
00070   void *user_context;
00071   CTHREAD *cthread;
00072   struct tagEVSOCKET *socket; 
00073   struct event timer_event;
00074   DLIST   object_list;
00075 } EVTHREAD;
00076 
00077 EVTHREAD *EVTHREAD_init(EVLOOP *loop, EVTHREAD_PROC thread_proc,  void *user_ctx);
00078 
00079 
00080 int EVTHREAD_start( EVTHREAD *thread, struct tagEVSOCKET *socket );
00081 
00082 int EVTHREAD_delay( EVTHREAD *thread, struct timeval delay );
00083 
00084 #if 0
00085 int EVTHREAD_dns_lookup ( EVTHREAD *thread, int  addr_family, const char *dns_name );
00086 
00087 int EVTHREAD_dns_lookup ( EVTHREAD *thread, int  addr_family, const char *dns_name )
00088 {
00089   CTHREAD *thread;
00090 
00091   switch( addr_family ) {
00092     case AF_INET:
00093       evdns_resolve_ipv6( dns_name, 0, evdns_callback_type callback, void *ptr);
00094       break;
00095     case AF_INET6:
00096       evdns_resolve_ipv6( dns_name, 0, evdns_callback_type callback, void *ptr);
00097       break;
00098   }
00099 
00100   CHREAD_yield();
00101 }

00128  * @defgroup EVTIMER
00129  * @brief timer object atached to event loop, a user mode thread is created when the event loop dispatches a timer event.
00130  * @{
00131  */

00140 } EVTIMERSTATE;

00175 // ---------------------------------------------------------------------------
00176 /**
00177  * @defgroup EVSOCKET
00178  * @brief a socket attached to user mode thread.
00179  *
00180  *  - a thread can either read from or write to a socket, not both at the same time.
00181  *  - a thread can read or write from one socket at a time.
00182  *
00183  * @{
00184  */
00185 
00186 typedef enum {
00187   EVSOCKET_STATE_INIT,
00188   EVSOCKET_STATE_CONNECTING,
00189   EVSOCKET_STATE_CONNECTED,
00190   EVSOCKET_STATE_READING,
00191   EVSOCKET_STATE_WRITING,
00192   EVSOCKET_STATE_CLOSED,
00193   EVSOCKET_STATE_ERROR,
00194 } EVSOCKET_STATE;
00195 
00196 
00197 typedef struct tagEVSOCKET {
00198   EVTHREAD_OBJECT object_base;
00199   
00200   int fd;
00201   struct event read_event;
00202   struct event write_event;
00203   
00204   EVSOCKET_STATE state;
00205   EVTIMER  *timer_idle_timeout; // idle timeout.
00206   EVTIMER  *timer_io_timeout; // timeout of current operation (read or write).
00207   
00208   EVLOOP *loop;
00209   EVTHREAD *thread;
00210 } 
00211   EVSOCKET;

00233 /**
00234  * @defgroup TCPACCEPTOR
00235  * @brief listener for tcp connections, a usermode thread is created for each new connection.
00236  *
00237  * @{
00238  */
00239 
00240 typedef int (*EVTHREAD_FACTORY) (int fd, EVTHREAD_PROC *proc, void **ctx );
00241
